byline.contributor: Mark Landler and Jason Horowitz reported from Washington, and Amy Chozick from Des Moines.
byline.original: By MARK LANDLER, AMY CHOZICK and JASON HOROWITZ

abstract: Pres Obama has stated he will not endorse a Democratic presidential candidate during primaries, but his staff is working closely with Hillary Clinton's staff and it is known that his aides view her as better qualified to protect Obama's legacy; Clinton campaign is maintaining solid contacts with staff throughout White House to ward off conflicts that could jeopardize an endorsement.
lead_paragraph: The White House is working with Hillary Clinton’s campaign in ways large and small. Their two staffs consult on issues and the positions she takes on the president’s policy priorities.

headline.main: Their Boss Stays on the Sideline, but Obama Aides Tilt to Clinton
headline.print_headline: Their Boss Stays on the Sideline, but Obama Aides Tilt to Clinton

snippet: The White House is working with Hillary Clinton’s campaign in ways large and small. Their two staffs consult on issues and the positions she takes on the president’s policy priorities.
